channel.title: NAIP imagery – The Biogoegraphy & Landscape Dynamics Lab
channel.description: Research focused on biogeography, spatial ecology and landscape change at Kent State University

item.title: Bing’s Global Ortho Project – an impressive imagery resource
item.dc:creator: tim.assal@gmail.com
item.description: A friend of mine recently turned me on to Bing Imagery (thanks Doug!) and I was really impressed. If you haven’t seen it yet it’s well worth a look: Bing has now completed their Global Ortho project (accessed through Bing’s map search engine). The archive covers the Continental United States and Western Europe at 30 … Continue reading Bing’s Global Ortho Project – an impressive imagery resource →
item.content:encoded:
A friend of mine recently turned me on to Bing Imagery (thanks Doug!) and I was really impressed. If you haven’t seen it yet it’s well worth a look:

Bing has now completed their Global Ortho project (accessed through Bing’s map search engine). The archive covers the Continental United States and Western Europe at 30 cm resolution. However other areas of the globe have excellent coverage as well. I’m not sure of the resolution, but it appears to have been collected at a finer scale than that of Google Earth. It is difficult to determine the date of the imagery. However, Martijn van Exel has a great post about this on his blog and he developed an interface through openstreetmap to determine imagery acquisition date. Unfortunately it only provides a range of imagery acquisition dates, but better than no date at all.Â  Check out http://mvexel.dev.openstreetmap.org/bing/ (zoom in on your area of interest pretty tight).

The imagery can only be viewed as a basemap in ArcGIS (to my knowledge). To add to an mxd: File/Add Data/Add Basemap/”Bing Maps Aerial”
